DOC.HEAD: Authorities Find Explosives, Arrest Top Drug Suspect
DOC.TEXT: Authorities discovered three tons of dynamite hidden in washing machines and other appliances warehoused in an area of the capital where drug barons planned to attack police, an official said. Also Friday, security forces said they captured a top Medellin drug cartel member wanted in the United States. In another case, authorities said a judge illegally freed the brother of one of Colombia's top cocaine kingpins, both of whom are also wanted by U.S. authorities. The dynamite was found Thursday night inside dozens of washing machines and other appliances stored in a warehouse in southern Bogota, the chief of the secret police, Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez, said Friday. ``This entire arsenal belonged to the Medellin cartel,'' he told reporters outside the warehouse. ``We have dismantled its principal terrorist network.'' The explosives were to be used to avenge the Dec. 15 police slaying of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, the No. 2 man in Medellin cartel, a police news release said. Security was increased in Bogota on Friday because authorities found evidence at the warehouse suggesting that either a bus or another large vehicle had already been packed with dynamite and sent into the city, Maza Marquez said. The number of military checkpoints was increased in the capital, and extra soldiers were posted at the Defense Ministry and police stations. The captured drug suspect, Jose Ocampo Obando, was arrested Friday in the banana-growing region of Uraba on Colombia's northern coast, the Defense Ministry said in a news release. The ministry did not say where Ocampo Obando is wanted in the United States. Colombia has extradited 11 suspected traffickers to the United States in the last four months. Ocampo Obando is considered by Colombian authorities to be the fifth-most important member of the Medellin cartel. In the western city of Cali, an army general said a judge illegally released the brother of the leader of the Cali cartel, the other main cocaine ring in Colombia. The judge had no reason to release Jorge Rodriguez Orejuela, who was wanted for extradition to the United States, army Gen. Jose Manuel Bonnett said at a news conference Friday in Cali. Rodriguez Orejuela's brother is Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela, said by Colombian authorities to be the billionaire leader of the Cali cartel based in the city of the same name. Since the government of President Virgilio Barco declared war on traffickers on Aug. 18, they have responded with 203 bombings that have killed 199 people and injured 1,238. Maza Marquez said that many of the car bombs used in the attacks had been prepared in the warehouse raided Thursday night. Police also received tips from callers saying they belonged to bands of criminals fighting for control of Rodriguez Gacha's drug empire, which generates billions of dollars each year. Authorities have said the struggle has resulted in the murders of 34 people during the last two weeks.
